Promoting Gender-Inclusive Growth in Central and

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Recognizing  the  pivotal  importance  of  equal  opportunities  for  women  and  men  in 
development, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) included gender equity as one of five drivers 
of change in its Strategy 2020.1 ADB's corporate results framework requires that 40% of all ADB 
projects and 50% of all Asian Development Fund (ADF) X-financed projects have "significant 
gender mainstreaming" by 2012.2  
 
2.  A special evaluation of the relevance, responsiveness, and results of ADB's support to 
gender  and  development  (GAD)  recently  completed  by  ADB's  Independent  Evaluation 
Department recommends (i) improving the outcome orientation of GAD goals and monitoring 
and evaluation, (ii) providing clarity to operationalize GAD goals in ADB operations in the 
context of Strategy 2020, and (iii) providing adequate financial resources to support policy 
implementation.3 The special evaluation study underscored several actions to facilitate gender 
mainstreaming in ADB operations, including (i) improving the capacity of developing member 
countries (DMCs) to systematically address gender concerns in development, (ii) assessing 
country-specific GAD issues and developing innovative strategies to promote gender equality, 
(iii) monitoring and evaluating projects with specific gender design features to ensure women's 
participation and access to project benefits, and (iv) strengthening ADB support at resident 
missions for improving gender mainstreaming performance. 
 
3.  The proposed technical assistance (TA)4 will strengthen the capacity of DMCs in Central 
and West Asia to (i) apply gender mainstreaming strategies in the design and implementation of 
projects and programs, (ii) support innovative and strategic approaches in the DMCs to promote 
gender equality and women's empowerment, and (iii) promote partnership and cooperation to 
enhance synergy. Activities will be supported through core areas of operations of ADB's Central 
and West Asia Department (CWRD), in which country-specific, innovative, and effective design 
features will be developed to provide equal opportunity for women and men to participate in and 
benefit from projects and programs. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  The  gender  mainstreaming  strategy  introduced  under  ADB's  Policy  on  Gender  and 
Development (1998) has contributed to progress in addressing gender concerns through ADB's 
country partnership strategy (CPS) and its lending and nonlending activities in DMCs in Central 
and West Asia. However, gaps and weaknesses in policy implementation continue. For instance, 
the  lack  of  clear  gender  targets  and  performance-monitoring  indicators  in  CPS  results 
frameworks  and  project  design-and-monitoring  frameworks  undermined  CWRD  and  ADB 
support at the level of both policy and operations of promoting gender equality and women's 
                                                
1  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
2  ADB loans and grants fall into four categories (i) gender equity theme, (ii) effective gender mainstreaming, (iii) 
some gender benefits, and (iv) no notable gender elements. The first two categories combined are referred to as 
projects with ―significant gender mainstreaming.‖ Until 2008, the data measured the number of loans and ADF 
grants. From 2009 onwards, for the purpose of ADB-wide consistency, the data refers to the number of "projects," 
which refers to (i) ordinary capital resources loans, (ii) ADF loans, (iii) ADF grants, and (iv) technical assistance 
projects. The term includes both projects and programs. The rating categories have been used since 1998 to 
monitor ADB's gender performance and were updated and clarified by the interdepartmental Technical Working 
Group on Gender Mainstreaming in ADB Operations in 2009. 
3  ADB. 2010. Special Evaluation Study on the Asian Development Bank's Support to Gender and Development – 
Phase I: Relevance, Responsiveness, and Results to Date. Manila. 
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 28 May 2010.

2     
 
empowerment and of gender impact assessment. In 2009, only 28% of CWRD's approved 
program and project loans were categorized as having "effective gender mainstreaming," while 
none met the criteria of a "gender equity theme." 5  
 
5.  Gender mainstreaming in CWRD operations faces several challenges: (i) infrastructure 
project design (e.g., for transport and energy) that normally does not easily accommodate 
gender mainstreaming; (ii) weak GAD strategies in CPSs and fewer projects that can directly 
address gender equality or women's empowerment (e.g., social services and basic rural and 
urban infrastructure); (iii) insufficient financial and technical capacity in DMCs to develop and 
adopt innovative and gender-responsive approaches to promote gender-inclusive economic 
growth; and (iv) too few GAD experts in resident missions (10 under CWRD) to support DMCs’ 
gender mainstreaming of ADB-financed projects.6 Foremost among the challenges is insufficient 
capacity in DMCs to apply gender mainstreaming strategies in the design and implementation of 
programs and projects. 
 
6.  A two-pronged approach in each country will be considered to tackle these challenges: (i) 
a  top–down  approach  with  emphasis  on  capacity  development  in  government  agencies 
(including ministries of women and project executing and implementing agencies) in developing 
and implementing gender-mainstreaming strategies and in monitoring and assessing gender 
equality results and (ii) a bottom–up approach to include women as active partners in ADB-
financed projects, empowering them through opportunities in gender-inclusive project planning, 
design, and implementation, thus improving women's access to and benefit from development 
projects.  
 
7.  Both approaches need in-depth country-specific gender assessments to identify entry 
points. In the transitional economies of the former Soviet Union, the emphasis will be put on 
how independence has affected men and women differently. Gender disparities in income and 
social  status  have  emerged  where  egalitarianism  was  once  a  defining  principle  of  official 
communist ideology. Widening gender gaps can now be observed in economic opportunities, 
access  to  social  services,  and  decision  making.  In  Pakistan,  culturally  founded  gender 
disparities call for support in implementing Pakistan’s national gender reform action plan and 
follow-up activities. Afghanistan will benefit from assistance to improve women's access to basic 
services and enable them to participate in national reconstruction. It is important when analyzing 
gender issues to keep in view country-specific culture and tradition and, in the context of 
countries’ economic profile, to identify appropriate entry points for gender mainstreaming.  
 
8.  Gender mainstreaming requires the identification and adoption of innovative approaches 
in CWRD operations. This is the case especially in sectors and/or projects that do not lend 
themselves easily to gender mainstreaming. Further, as Strategy 2020 emphasizes increased 
private sector operations to sustain economic growth in the long run, there is a need to develop 
and scale up innovative approaches to gender mainstreaming in public–private partnership 
projects. 
 
9.  In-country consultations with government agencies, nongovernment and civil society 
organizations, and development partners found that the TA was essential to support DMCs in 
Central and West Asia and to enable CWRD to better assist DMCs in systematically addressing

Cooperation Fund to support GAD policy implementation in all ADB operations, the TA will pave 
the way for CWRD to institutionalize in its own structure, mechanisms, and approaches ways to 
accelerate gender mainstreaming in its operations to meet Strategy 2020 targets. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The TA promotes gender-inclusive growth by helping DMCs in Central and West Asia to 
make progress in achieving gender equality and women's empowerment, hence contributing to 
achieving Millennium Development Goals. Its outcome is to improve capacity in DMCs in gender 
mainstreaming through the planning, design, implementation, and performance monitoring of 
gender-inclusive programs and projects to improve gender equality. Increased DMC ownership 
and  application  of  GAD  strategy  in  development  projects  will  enable  more  gender 
mainstreaming in ADB-financed projects.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  Output 1: Capacity to collect sex-disaggregated data is enhanced in participating 
DMCs. Sex-disaggregated statistics are largely absent, and the capacity of DMCs to collect 
data to monitor and assess the gender impacts of programs and projects is generally weak at 
the country, sector, and project level. External support for capacity development is urgently 
needed to provide baseline data for reference when preparing country strategies and projects, 
monitoring  progress,  evaluating  impact,  and  comparatively  analyzing  in-country  and  cross-
border  issues  and  achievements  (e.g.,  under  the  ADB-supported  Central  Asia  Regional 
Economic Cooperation program7). Capacity development in sex-disaggregated data collection 
will target key government agencies tasked with national or sector- and project-specific data 
collection,  including  the  line  ministries  and  project  executing  and  implementing  agencies 
involved with ADB-financed projects. A basic policy framework will be developed to integrate 
sex-disaggregated data collection in national statistical systems to ensure sustainability. 
 
12.  Output  2:  Participatory  country  gender  assessments  completed.  Participatory 
gender assessments will identify and document differences in gender roles, activities, needs, 
and  opportunities  in  specific  countries.  ADB’s  first  country  gender  assessment  (CGA)  for 
Armenia and Georgia will be prepared using a participatory approach that includes stakeholder 
consultations and workshops to ensure inclusiveness and awareness at all levels. The CGAs 
will conduct gender issues analysis on (i) the different roles of women and men in society, 
including their participation in household and public economies; (ii) gender disparities in access 
to, control over, and the use of assets and productive resources; (iii) human development 
indicators; (iv) gender inequality in participation in decision-making locally and nationally; and (v) 
laws, institutional frameworks, norms, and other social and cultural practices that cause gender 
inequality. The CGAs completed earlier with ADB assistance8 will be updated as necessary for 
CPS  preparation  and  will  support  country-  and  sector-specific  GAD  dialogue.  The  CGAs 
completed under the TA will be published and used as key inputs for CPS preparation.9 The 
CGAs will also provide data and information for country- and project-specific gender action 
plans, CPS results frameworks, and project design and monitoring frameworks. In particular,

country gender action plans will outline the strategies, actions, and outputs that a DMC aims to 
pursue for gender equality in partnership with ADB.  
 
13.  Output 3: 15–20 gender mainstreaming pilot projects developed and implemented. 
Through the posting of GAD experts in CWRD resident missions and the timely provision of 
technical support to executing agencies and ADB project staff, the TA will support DMCs in 
developing and applying innovative, socially inclusive, and gender-responsive approaches to 
gender mainstreaming. One pilot subproject will be developed in each of the participating DMCs 
in year 1 and 2 of the project duration to showcase effective gender mainstreaming in sectors or 
projects  that  do  not  lend  themselves  easily  to  gender  mainstreaming  (e.g.,  energy  and 
transport). The subprojects may include (i) income-generating project components for women, 
especially project components to promote women’s entrepreneurship and leadership skills; (ii) 
microfinance  that  caters  to  women's  needs;  (iii)  public–private  partnerships  that  support 
women's business endeavors; (iv) customer services and client-oriented project development 
and marketing; and (v) other country-specific project proposals that promote gender equality 
and women's empowerment. The pilot subprojects will be considered for financing by ADB or 
other development partners. The TA will assist the review and documentation of new and 
innovative  approaches  to  gender  mainstreaming  in  traditional  sectors  such  as  social  and 
financial  services,  as  these  sectors  evolve  with  changing  economic,  social,  and  political 
environment  that  is  characteristic  of  economies  in  transition  in  Central  and West  Asia.  A 
compilation  of  implemented  projects  will  be  published  to  showcase  effective  gender 
mainstreaming in participating DMCs.  
 
14.  Output 4: GAD network reinforced and coordinated. Partnership and networking with 
development partners, local women's groups; nongovernment organizations; research institutes; 
and, where they exist, national women's associations will be supported to promote knowledge-
sharing and synergies. In particular, close coordination and cooperation where feasible with 
other  development  partners  such  as  United  Nations  agencies,  the  World  Bank,  bilateral 
development agencies, and development partners' local consultative subgroups on GAD will 
result in more consistent dialogue on the development and implementation of GAD policies and 
strategies  nationally.  Innovative  and  strategic  gender  mainstreaming  approaches  will  be 
developed with wider stakeholder participation to support participating DMCs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The cost of the TA is estimated at $3,550,000, with $3,200,000 financed as a grant from 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The governments of the 10 participating 
DMCs will provide in-kind contributions totaling $350,000. The detailed cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The TA will be implemented over 39 months from August 2010 to November 2013, 
including (i) a 3-month inception period to confirm the participation of the DMCs and recruit 
consultants and (ii) 36 months of actual TA delivery.  
 
17.  While all DMCs in Central and West Asia are invited to participate in the TA, the extent 
and specifics of activities may vary from country to country based on local needs. ADB will be 
the executing agency. Coordination and field activities will be assigned to consultants engaged 
individually in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended

5 
 
from time to time). Disbursement under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB's Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2008, as amended from time to time).  
 
18.  To efficiently manage implementation, the DMCs will be grouped into four regions: (i) 
Central  Asia  region  with  Kazakhstan,  Kyrgyz  Republic,  Tajikistan,  Turkmenistan,  and 
Uzbekistan; (ii) Caucasus region with Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Georgia; (iii) Afghanistan; and 
(iv)  Pakistan.  In  each  country,  the  GAD  focal  group  comprising  government  agencies, 
nongovernment  organizations,  and  other  local stakeholders  will  support TA  implementation 
through (i) the facilitation of government decision-making processes, (ii) cross-agency liaison 
and  assistance  in  planning  training  and  workshops,  and  (iii)  feedback  on  implementation 
progress  for  effective  monitoring  and  evaluation.  No  TA  activity  will  commence  in  any 
participating DMC until the DMC provides a no-objection letter.  
 
19.  A TA management team will be established in CWRD's Gender, Climate Change, and 
Safeguards Unit. TA coordination will be carried out by CWRD's GAD specialist, assisted by one 
national consultant as TA coordinator and one TA administrator based at ADB headquarters. 
DMCs will be assisted by national consultants. One national consultant will be contracted as 
subregional project manager to coordinate and monitor TA implementation in Central Asia and 
in  the  Caucasus  region  from  ADB's  office  in  Almaty,  Kazakhstan.  The  coordination  and 
monitoring of TA implementation in Afghanistan and Pakistan will be done through the resident 
missions. Eight national consultants will be required for a total of 231 person-months, as will 3 
international consultants be engaged intermittently for a total of 18 person-months. The use of 
individual consultants was adopted due to the nature of the TA, which aims to develop the 
capacity of the DMCs by strengthening ADB support at resident missions. All CWRD resident 
missions have been consulted and will provide administrative and logistical support for TA 
implementation. 
 
20.  TA review will be conducted by region annually or as needed. A brief review will be 
undertaken following TA inception to assess DMC participation and update key outputs and 
activities as necessary. A full accomplishment assessment will be undertaken at TA completion 
to report on progress in gender mainstreaming in CWRD operations under the new institutional 
mechanism introduced for GAD support. The results of the TA will be disseminated among 
participating countries and within ADB through both country and regional workshops and a 
conference. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
21.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $3,200,000 on a grant basis for Promoting Gender-Inclusive 
Growth in Central and West Asia Developing Member Countries.

TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Implementation Arrangements, Responsibilities, Work Modality, and Time Frame 
 
1.  For  effective  technical  assistance  (TA)  implementation,  the  10  developing  member 
countries  (DMCs)  in  Central  and  West  Asia  covered  under  the  Central  and  West  Asia 
Department (CWRD) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) are grouped into four regions: (i) 
Central  Asia  region  with  Kazakhstan,  Kyrgyz  Republic,  Tajikistan,  Turkmenistan,  and 
Uzbekistan; (ii) Caucasus region with Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Georgia; (iii) Afghanistan; and 
(iv) Pakistan. The TA management team at headquarters will manage the TA in the Central Asia 
region and the Caucasus region through one subregional project management team based in 
ADB's office in Almaty, Kazakhstan, and in Afghanistan and Pakistan through the resident 
missions.  
 
2.  The gender and development specialist of CWRD, the task manager for the TA, will lead 
the  TA  management  team  at  ADB  headquarters,  comprising  one  TA  coordinator,  one  TA 
administrator,  and  one  international  consultant.  A  technical  committee  comprising  CWRD 
gender  specialists,  gender  focal  points  at  resident  missions  and  sector  divisions  will  be 
established to provide technical inputs toward achieving TA objectives in consultation with 
ADB's gender community of practice. A gender and development (GAD) focal group comprising 
government agencies, nongovernment organization (NGOs), and other local stakeholders will 
be organized in each of the 10 DMCs to serve as a catalyst for country inputs and feedback 
during TA implementation.  
 
3.  National  consultant  will  be contracted  in Georgia to  cover the  Caucasus  region,  in 
Uzbekistan to cover Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan, in Kyrgyz Republic to cover Kyrgyz Republic 
and  Tajikistan.  One  national  consultant  will  be  required  in  Afghanistan  and  two  national 
consultants will be required in Pakistan because of the larger volume of work. Central Asia and 
Caucasus region together will be supported by one international consultant, and Afghanistan 
and Pakistan together will be supported by one international consultant. National consultants in 
each country will work closely together with resident missions, government institutions, national 
women's  associations  where  they  exist,  local  NGOs,  national  research  institutes,  and 
development  partners.  They  will  establish  GAD  focal  groups  for  each  country.  National 
consultants will work in the field as required. 
 
4.  Three international consultants will be contracted to work intermittently for a total of 18 
person-months, assisting in data generation and analysis and in compiling and editing the 
knowledge products for publication. Of the three international consultants, one will be based in 
ADB  headquarters  while  the  other  two  will  work  directly  with  the  regional  teams.  The 
international consultants will provide  support in preparing basic statistic policy frameworks, 
country  learning  events,  case  studies,  country  gender  assessment  (CGA)  reports,  country 
gender action plans, and TA reports.  
 
5.  The performance of TA consultants will be closely monitored through quarterly work 
plans and progress reports. An annual country accomplishment report will be prepared by the 
consultants for each country and submitted to ADB through the subregional project manager for 
Central Asia and the Caucasus, and in Afghanistan and Pakistan through the resident missions. 
The TA coordinator and headquarters-based international consultant will use the country reports 
as  inputs  to  an  annual  TA  accomplishment  report  for  all  regions.  The  performance  of  all 
consultants will be monitored at the end of each year through a separate annual performance

Appendix 3     11 
 
review by CWRD's gender and development specialist as the TA task manager.  The specific 
terms of reference for consultants are as follows. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
1.  ADB Headquarters-Based TA Administrator (1 individual, total of 39 person- 
months) 
6.  Objective/purpose of assignment. The ADB headquarter-based TA administrator will 
be responsible for the TA administration.  
 
7.  Scope  of work. The TA administrator's tasks will include but not be limited to the 
following: 
(i)  Monitor physical progress in projects/TA implementation, for example, by following 
up on outstanding obligations of EAs to expedite procurement/contract awards; 
monitoring of progress in terms of outputs and  deliverables, following up 
submission of project reports, financial statements, etc.; maintaining related 
documents, records and files for delegated projects; maintaining computer-based 
information system for project administration matters; 
(ii)  Assist in consultants recruitment, contract variation; 
(iii)  Maintain CWRD's Gender and Development Website and online Gender Network; 
(iv)  Assist in preparing project briefs, presentation materials; and 
(v)  Assist TA coordinator in TA implementation (budget management, reportorial 
requirements). 
2.  ADB Headquarters-Based TA Coordinator/GAD Consultant (1 individual, total 
of 39 person-months) 
8.  Objective/purpose  of  the  assignment.  The  ADB  headquarters-based  national 
consultant  will  provide  direct  support  to  the  TA  task  manager  (i.e.,  CWRD  gender  and 
development specialist). He or she will contribute to achieving all TA activities to enhance 
gender equality in CWRD operations. 
 
9.  Scope of work. The TA coordinator's tasks will include but not be limited to the following: 
(i)  review all TA outputs;  
(ii)  provide technical and logistic support for in-country and regional learning events; 
(iii)  coordinate the activities of subregional project managers and resident mission 
gender focal points and safeguards unit in the Pakistan Resident Mission through 
weekly telephone conferences and technical support; 
(iv)  establish CWRD's technical gender committee; 
(v)  review all gender action plans for CWRD projects; 
(vi)  review all project proposals; and 
(vii)  establish a gender database for CWRD. 
 
3.  Subregional Project Manager (1 individual, total of 24 person-months) 
10.  Objective/purpose of the assignment. The subregional project manager will lead in 
the planning, monitoring, and assessment activities of the subregional project management

C.  International Consultants 
 
  1.  ADB Headquarters-Based Consultant (1 individual, total of 6 person-months) 
 
14.  Objective/purpose  of  the  assignment. The headquarters-based  consultant  will  be 
responsible for producing knowledge products resulting from the project and providing technical 
inputs for developing the capacity of national consultants. He or she will assure the quality of all 
products developed through the project at headquarters, in subregions, and in countries.  
 
15.  Scope of work. The international consultant's tasks will include but not be limited to the 
following: 
(i)  advise  on  the  development  of  policy  framework  for  sex-disaggregated  data 
collection; 
(ii)  edit project proposals; 
(iii)  edit and finalize all reports, including case studies, CGAs, TA reports, etc.; 
(iv)  organize  the  inception  meeting,  midterm  workshop,  and  end-of-project 
conference; 
(v)  serve as a resource person in the inception meeting, midterm seminar, end-of-
project conference, and other project events; and 
(vi)  support the CWRD GAD network with technical inputs. 
 
2.  International Consultants (2 individuals, total of 12 person-months) 
 
16.  Objective/purpose  of the  assignment. The international consultants will assist the 
subregional project manager and national consultants in each country in their areas in delivering 
TA outputs. Their primary tasks are to advise on all aspects of project implementation, lead the 
production of regional and country-based knowledge products; and act as lead facilitators in 
gender training at the region and country level. 
 
17.  Scope of work. The international consultants’ tasks will include but not be limited to the 
following: 
(i)  conduct CGAs for Armenia and Georgia; 
(ii)  update CGAs for Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, and Uzbekistan; 
(iii)  document pilot projects for the production of the compiled report on pilot projects; 
(iv)  provide inputs to CPS preparation as required; 
(v)  guide national consultants and assist in their capacity development; 
(vi)  take lead role in consolidated reporting; 
(vii)  serve as resource speakers in the inception meeting, midterm seminar, end-of-
project conference, and other project events; and 
(viii)  assist in establishing GAD focal groups. 
 
D.  Gender and Development Focal Groups in Each DMC 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
 members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.  
18.  The GAD focal groups comprising relevant government agencies, NGOs, and other local 
stakeholders (e.g., national women's associations where they exist) in each of the 10 DMCs will 
serve as catalysts for country-specific inputs and feedback during TA implementation. The

14     Appendix 3 
 
contributions  of  the  GAD  focal  group  members  will  be  instrumental  in  sustaining  project 
outcomes, as these groups will continue to serve as resources and mechanisms for developing 
and implementing GAD-related policies, strategies, and programs. The GAD focal group will 
meet quarterly to provide inputs on implementation issues. 
 
E.  Technical Committee at Headquarters and Resident Missions 
 
19.  The technical committee comprising CWRD gender and development specialists and 
gender focal points at resident missions and sector divisions will provide technical inputs toward 
achieving TA objectives in consultation with ADB's gender community of practice. Specifically, 
the technical committee will provide advice on major TA activities including developing capacity 
to  collect  sex-disaggregated  data,  participatory  CGA,  developing  mechanisms  for  gender 
mainstreaming in programs and projects, and project proposal selection based on CWRD’s 
project pipeline. The technical committee will meet quarterly and resident mission gender focal 
points will be connected through videoconferencing.
